pullRequest.body:
Another step towards proving that a non-empty the real interval $[x,y]$ has boundary ${ x,y }$ (as a manifold).

---

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [390dfec8cd](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15891/commits/390dfec8cd9f00d3546366b58abea40a4d7b2f0e)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IccLeftChart_extend_interior_pos`
`+ IccLeftChart_extend_left_eq`
`+ IccLeftChart_extend_left_mem_frontier`
`+ IccRightChart_extend_right_eq`
`+ IccRightChart_extend_right_mem_frontier`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#15890~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

@YaelDillies In this PR, I'm adding definitions for "the left endpoint of `Icc a b`, as a term of type `Icc a b`" (and similar). I'm not perfectly happy with the naming `left` and `right` for the endpoints; there is one place in this PR where I had to fix a name conflict. Do you have ideas for a better name?

Isn't that just `‚ä•` and `‚ä§`? See `Set.Icc.orderBot` and `Set.Icc.orderTop`.

One should check the performance is not too bad, but making `Set.Icc.orderBot` and `Set.Icc.orderTop` instances taking in `Fact (a ‚â§ b)` sounds reasonable, and well-motivated by your use-case.
Thanks for pointing this out! I'll take a look.
I checked: `Order/LatticeIntervals.lean` in fact contains such instances by now, so there was in fact nothing to do for me.
I'm open to the argument that this lemma (and its right counterpart) is sufficiently trivial to be inlined.
This has nothing to do with the manifold setup. Shouldn't this be available to anyone working with the set `Icc`?
Good point: I moved this next to the definition of `Set.Icc`. The names `Icc.left` and `Icc.right` might cause conflicts; if you prefer a different name, I'm open to changing it.

I'd appreciate help with this question: I'm not sure how to solve this. Removing `hxy_twice`, even if writing `include hxy in` before the theorem, yields an error "failed to synthesize Fact (x ‚â§ y)".

The same issue appears three more times below.
@YaelDillies I know you're not a differential geometer, but since you're looking right now: do you happen to know the answer? This is just a Lean question, I presume.

pullRequest.title: feat: lemmas about the left and right boundary point under `Icc{Left,Right}Chart`

nodes.body:
This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#15890~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

@YaelDillies In this PR, I'm adding definitions for "the left endpoint of `Icc a b`, as a term of type `Icc a b`" (and similar). I'm not perfectly happy with the naming `left` and `right` for the endpoints; there is one place in this PR where I had to fix a name conflict. Do you have ideas for a better name?

Isn't that just `‚ä•` and `‚ä§`? See `Set.Icc.orderBot` and `Set.Icc.orderTop`.

One should check the performance is not too bad, but making `Set.Icc.orderBot` and `Set.Icc.orderTop` instances taking in `Fact (a ‚â§ b)` sounds reasonable, and well-motivated by your use-case.
Thanks for pointing this out! I'll take a look.
I checked: `Order/LatticeIntervals.lean` in fact contains such instances by now, so there was in fact nothing to do for me.
